topic: Twice proves there is an audience thirsty for K-pop in Australia

ideas.title: Moomba Moments
ideas.premise: The Moomba King and Queen (traditionally daggy Aussie icons) are bewildered as thousands wearing Twice lightsticks swamp Birrarung Marr, eclipsing their parade.
ideas.why_funny: Juxtaposition of Aussie bogan culture with K-Pop mania is unexpected and hilarious.

ideas.title: Diljit's Dilemma
ideas.premise: Diljit Dosanjh, holding a Vegemite toast, nervously watches a stadium filling up faster for Twice than his Aura concert the previous night.
ideas.why_funny: Plays on celebrity rivalry and the unexpected popularity contrast, plus Vegemite detail.

ideas.title: K-Pop Coffee
ideas.premise: A barista in Degraves Street struggles to spell out 'Nayeon' with latte art as a long queue of Once members impatiently waits for their K-Pop themed coffees.
ideas.why_funny: Melbourne is famous for its coffee culture, adding a humorous local touch.

ideas.title: Festival Frenzy
ideas.premise: Rod Laver Arena transforms, covered with flashing lights & screaming fans; a bewildered security guard yells 'Oi! No moshing! It's K-Pop, not a heavy metal concert!'
ideas.why_funny: Misunderstanding of K-Pop concert etiquette, funny Aussie slang.

ideas.title: Koala Karaoke
ideas.premise: A koala in the Royal Botanic Gardens is perched on a eucalyptus tree trying to sing along to 'What is Love?' but only managing strangled guttural noises.
ideas.why_funny: Australian wildlife trying to participate in K-Pop, inherently absurd.

headlines.title: Twice proves there is an audience thirsty for K-pop in Australia
headlines.summary: Next stop Melbourne for multinational K-pop group Twice after Sydney concerts are lapped up by excited fans.

headlines.title: Kajal Aggarwal enjoys Diljit Dosanjh's epic Aura concert in Australia with husband Gautam Kitchlu
headlines.summary: Kajal Aggarwal was thrilled to attend Diljit Dosanjh's electrifying AURA concert in Australia, moving to the rhythm of his popular tracks. While explo
